SAMS

Nitrogen (N):

Optimal Range: 50–200 ppm (parts per million)

Deficient: Below 50 ppm

Excess: Above 200 ppm (too much nitrogen can lead to excessive foliage growth at the expense of fruit production)

Phosphorus (P):

Optimal Range: 30–60 ppm

Deficient: Below 30 ppm

Excess: Above 60 ppm (high phosphorus levels may interfere with other nutrient uptake like zinc and iron)

Potassium (K):

Optimal Range: 200–400 ppm

Deficient: Below 200 ppm

Excess: Above 400 ppm (can inhibit calcium and magnesium uptake)

Additional Considerations:

Soil pH: Ensure the soil pH is between 6.0–6.8 for optimal nutrient availability. If the pH is off, the plant may not effectively absorb the nutrients even if NPK levels are ideal.

Growth Stages: Nutrient needs may vary slightly during different growth stages (seedling, flowering, fruiting). For example:

Higher nitrogen during the vegetative growth stage.

More phosphorus during flowering and early fruiting.

Increased potassium during fruit development for better fruit quality.

By monitoring these thresholds, you can maintain the right balance of nutrients for healthy tomato plant growth.
